title.narrative: Support to FSH project on TNFD

description.narrative: Provide support to Finance Sector Hub (FSH) project on the Task Force on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD).

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
Output 3: Solutions for sustainable biodiversity management (including forests), generated, disseminated, advocated and adopted
3.1 Number of events at which the NYDF, and related forest issues, is advanced 3.2 Number of signatories of governments, companies and communities who have demonstrated commitment and who have undertaken concrete steps to achieve one or more of the NYDF goals 3.3 Number of knowledge management products and solutions produced on sustainable forestry, deforestation-free commodities and reforestation, among other NYDF-related themes, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences, where appropriate 3.4 Number of indigenous peoples and local communities engaged in forest-related global events, advocating for a land rights, forest protection, disaggregated by sex of participants 3.5 Number of knowledge products, events, calls, workshops and meetings to support Convention Secretariats, on a demand-driven basis

comment.narrative: 3.1 Number of events at which the NYDF, and related forest issues, is advanced: 0 3.2 Number of signatories of governments, companies and communities who have demonstrated commitment and who have undertaken concrete steps to achieve one or more of the NYDF goals: 189 3.3 Number of knowledge management products and solutions produced on sustainable forestry, deforestation-free commodities and reforestation, among other NYDF-related themes, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences, where appropriate: 0 3.4 Number of indigenous peoples and local communities engaged in forest-related global events, advocating for a land rights, forest protection, disaggregated by sex of participants: 0 3.5 Number of knowledge products, events, calls, workshops and meetings to support Convention Secretariats, on a demand-driven basis: 0

3.1 Number of events at which the NYDF, and related forest issues, is advanced: 6 3.2 Number of signatories of governments, companies and communities who have demonstrated commitment and who have undertaken concrete steps to achieve one or more of the NYDF goals: 400 3.3 Number of knowledge management products and solutions produced on sustainable forestry, deforestation-free commodities and reforestation, among other NYDF-related themes, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences, where appropriate: 25 3.4 Number of indigenous peoples and local communities engaged in forest-related global events, advocating for a land rights, forest protection, disaggregated by sex of participants: 200 3.5 Number of knowledge products, events, calls, workshops and meetings to support Convention Secretariats, on a demand-driven basis: 3 major meetings

3.1 Number of events at which the NYDF, and related forest issues, is advanced: RESULT: 29 – NYDF: 5 (NYDF Refresh launch at Global Landscapes Forum, Deforestation-free Commodities event at ISAF Japan, NYDF Commitments to Action event during UNFCCC COP26 at Global Landscapes Forum, 2 Forest Solutions Dialogues); work on spatial tools for development planning: 24 (17 ELSA workshops, 7 NASA roundtables) 3.2 Number of signatories of governments, companies and communities who have demonstrated commitment and who have undertaken concrete steps to achieve one or more of the NYDF goals: RESULT: 219 endorsers total (24 new NYDF endorsers have been added since the start of the project). Additionally, COP26 was a pivotal moment for forest commitments where many public and private sector commitments aligned with the NYDF goal of halting deforestation by 2030 were made including, 141 countries committing to the Glasgow Leaders Declaration on Forests and Land Use, 12 companies committed to the Agricultural Commodity Corporate Statement of Purpose, and 30 financial institutions committed to eliminating investments in agricultural commodity-driven deforestation. 3.3 Number of knowledge management products and solutions produced on sustainable forestry, deforestation-free commodities and reforestation, among other NYDF-related themes, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences, where appropriate: RESULT: 10 – NYDF: 8 (2 NBS in NDC country briefings; 3 NYDF Assessment reports and publications; 1 Revised NYDF Declaration with updated preamble and goals; 2 new blogs to discuss new restoration data and the outcomes of COP26); work on spatial tools for development planning: 1 (Letter Towards monitoring forest ecosystem integrity within the Post-2020 biodiversity framework); work supporting the CBD: 1 (the Creating a Nature-Positive Future Global Report and the 197 ABT-11 Country Dossiers are key knowledge products for Parties of the Convention on Biological Diversity to enhance the quantity and quality of protected and conserved areas to achieve biodiversity as well as climate change and sustainable development priorities: 1 global report, 197 Country Dossiers) 3.4 Number of indigenous peoples and local communities engaged in forest-related global events, advocating for a land rights, forest protection, disaggregated by sex of participants: RESULT: 143 – NYDF: 33 Indigenous Peoples and local communities (6 M, 1 F participated in NYDF Refresh working group and consultations calls and consultations; 1 M + 1 F panelists at NYDF Refresh virtual launch event, October 2021; 1 F panelist at NYDF event during UNFCC COP26 at Global Landscapes Forum, November 2021; 12 F + 11 M in 2 meetings with the Global Alliance for Territorial Communities to consult on the NYDF Refresh and IPLC Action Plan); work on spatial tools for development planning: 10 IPLC representatives in ELSA workshops for Peru and Ecuador; Equator Initiative: 100 in various events 3.5 Number of knowledge products, events, calls, workshops and meetings to support Convention Secretariats, on a demand-driven basis: RESULT: 1 major meeting (UNFCCC COP26). The NYDF Platform played a leading role, through engagement with the UK COP26 team, in ensuring that forests and nature was one of the pillars of the COP26 Presidency, and in setting the ambition and shaping the narrative for a World Leaders Summit event on forests and land use. Additionally, leading up to COP26 and to prepare for the NYDF Refresh launch event in October 2021, the NYDF Platform organized 9 group consultation sessions with the NYDF refresh working group and 30 bilateral meetings with members of the NYDF community (including governments, private sector, Indigenous Peoples, and donors) to collect feedback and inputs on the NYDF Goals and role of the Platform, resulting in a revised set of forest goals and increased endorser engagement ahead of COP26.
